p: Data regarding the relationship between COVID-19 and chemokine dysregulation are still scanty, but are increasingly being reported. Although preliminary, the available data provided by both clinical and in vitro studies suggest possible similarities between what was observed after SARS-Cov and MERS-Cov infection. Overall, an increased production of pro-inflammatory chemokines (mainly CXCL10 and CXCL8) seems to characterize also COVID-19 infection.
